elements.content: Three 3D multifunctional microporous metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) (H4ABTC = 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide, and JUC = Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of a rigid tetra-carboxylate ligand H4ABTC and corresponding transition metal salts under mild conditions. X-ray crystallography reveals that their topologies are based on NbO (JUC-62) and PtS (JUC-63 and JUC-64) nets, constructed of 4-connected rectangular ABTC4− units with 4-connected square paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 secondary building units (SBUs), tetrahedral bimetallic Cd2(CO2)4(DMF)3 SBUs, and tetrahedral monometallic Mn(CO2)4(DMF)3 SBUs, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that JUC-62 and JUC-63 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 392 and 402 nm, respectively.

elements.content: Metal−organic framework (MOF) design and construction is currently a flourishing field of research owing to the intriguing molecular topologies and the potentially exploitable adsorption, catalytic, fluorescence, and magnetic properties. The recent discovery that MOFs take up significant amounts of hydrogen has spurred interest in these materials as possible storage media for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles. Meanwhile an important aspect of this relatively new chemistry is the analysis and direction of network topologies of the MOFs, which is a precondition to make true and significant development. In particular, exploring highly symmetrical multifunctional organic ligands and suitable metal salts in a design strategy to construct coordination complexes with special topologies is of higher interest, due to the predictability of the resulting networks. Some structures of minerals, such as quartz diamond, rutile, perovsktie, NbO, PtS, and feldspar, have been artificially produced by replacing monatomic anions (O2−, S2−) with polyatomic organic ligands as linkers and utilizing the well-defined coordination geometries of metal centers as nodes. Among an infinite number of possibilities, the three-dimensional (3-D) NbO network was identified as the default using square-planar 4-connected nodes, and PtS networks could be constructed when using both square-planar and tetrahedral 4-connected nodes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic framework (MOF) design and construction is currently a flourishing field of research owing to the intriguing molecular topologies and the potentially exploitable adsorption, catalytic, fluorescence, and magnetic properties. The recent discovery that MOFs take up significant amounts of hydrogen has spurred interest in these materials as possible storage media for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles. Meanwhile an important aspect of this relatively new chemistry is the analysis and direction of network topologies of the MOFs, which is a precondition to make true and significant development. In particular, exploring highly symmetrical multifunctional organic ligands and suitable metal salts in a design strategy to construct coordination complexes with special topologies is of higher interest, due to the predictability of the resulting networks. Some structures of minerals, such as quartz diamond, rutile, perovsktie, NbO, PtS, and feldspar, have been artificially produced by replacing monatomic anions (O2-, S2-) with polyatomic organic ligands as linkers and utilizing the well-defined coordination geometries of metal centers as nodes. Among an infinite number of possibilities, the three-dimensional (3-D) NbO network was identified as the default using square-planar 4-connected nodes, and PtS networks could be constructed when using both square-planar and tetrahedral 4-connected nodes.

elements.content: Recently, we designed a tetra-carboxylate ligand, 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid (H4ABTC), which can act as a rigid rectangular-planar 4-connected ligand. We expect to prepare some microporous MOFs with 4-connected topologies from different coordination geometric transition metal ions with this ligand. During the course of our work, three metal-organic frameworks were reported on this ligand. Herein, we will describe three compounds Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) (H4ABTC = 3,3′,5,5′-azobenzenetetracarboxylic acid, DMF = N,N′-dimethylformamide, and JUC = Jilin University China), possessing NbO and PtS net topologies, respectively, from Cu2+, Cd2+, or Mn2+ ions with the H4ABTC ligand. Of further interest, the high-pressure hydrogen storage and fluorescence properties have been examined.

Of further interest, the high-pressure hydrogen storage and fluorescence properties have been examined.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a LS55 luminescence spectrometer. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under oxygen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents and solvents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on a LS55 luminescence spectrometer. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under oxygen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å).

elements.content: A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·(H2O)2.5 (24 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4ABTC (18 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in DMF/ethanol/H2O (5:3:1) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. Sufficient 2 M HNO3 was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at 60 °C for 2 days to give blue-green, polyhedral crystals. Yield: 61% (based on H4ABTC). Elemental anal. Calcd C22H26N4O13Cu2 (680): C, 38.82; H, 3.85; N, 8.24. Found: C, 38.91; H, 3.78; N, 8.32.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for JUC-62, JUC-63, and JUC-64 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature by using the ω-scan technique. Raw data for all structures were processed using SAINT and absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the program SHELXTL. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions. For JUC-62, guest solvent molecules were highly disordered and were impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters were summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles of JUC-62, JUC-63, and JUC-64 are listed in Table and , respectively. Crystal drawings were produced by Cerius2 soft. CCDC-666395 (JUC-62), CCDC-666396 (JUC-63), and CCDC-666397 (JUC-64) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, U.K.; fax: (44) 1223-336-003; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

X-ray Crystallographic Study

Diffraction intensities for JUC-62, JUC-63, and JUC-64 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature by using the ω-scan technique. Raw data for all structures were processed using SAINT and absorption corrections were applied using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the program SHELXTL. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions. For JUC-62, guest solvent molecules were highly disordered and were impossible to refine using conventional discrete-atom models. To resolve these issues, the contribution of solvent electron density was removed by the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON. Pertinent crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters were summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and bond angles of JUC-62, JUC-63, and JUC-64 are listed in Table  and , respectively. Crystal drawings were produced by Cerius2 soft. CCDC-666395 (JUC-62), CCDC-666396 (JUC-63), and CCDC-666397 (JUC-64) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, U.K.; fax: (44) 1223-336-003; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

High-pressure hydrogen sorption isotherm measurements on JUC-62 were recorded using a RUBOTHERM magnetic suspension balance (Ankersmid B.V., Netherlands). High purity hydrogen (99.999%) was used for the measurement. About 150 mg of as-synthesized blue-green crystalline sample of JUC-62 was immersed in acetone for 2 h, and fresh acetone was added after the extract was decanted, which was operated at least five times. Then the crystals were allowed to immerse in acetone for 24 h to remove the guest solvates (DMF and H2O). After the removal of acetone by decanting, the sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum (<10−3 Torr) at room temperature overnight. Before the measurement, the sample was activated under 10−5 Torr at 120 °C for 24 h on the apparatus resulting in purple crystalline material, which can remove the terminal water molecules bound with Cu(II) ions to introduce open metal sites.
elements.clean_text:
High-Pressure Hydrogen Sorption Measurement

High-pressure hydrogen sorption isotherm measurements on JUC-62 were recorded using a RUBOTHERM magnetic suspension balance (Ankersmid B.V., Netherlands). High purity hydrogen (99.999%) was used for the measurement. About 150 mg of as-synthesized blue-green crystalline sample of JUC-62 was immersed in acetone for 2 h, and fresh acetone was added after the extract was decanted, which was operated at least five times. Then the crystals were allowed to immerse in acetone for 24 h to remove the guest solvates (DMF and H2O). After the removal of acetone by decanting, the sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum (<10-3 Torr) at room temperature overnight. Before the measurement, the sample was activated under 10-5 Torr at 120 °C for 24 h on the apparatus resulting in purple crystalline material, which can remove the terminal water molecules bound with Cu(II) ions to introduce open metal sites.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2·(H2O)2.5, Cd(NO3)2·(H2O)4, or MnCl2·(H2O)4 with H4ABTC organic linker in a slightly acidified mixture DMF/EtOH/H2O or DMF/glycol/H2O readily led to highly crystalline Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64), respectively, in high yield. Addition of a small amount of dilute nitric/muriatic acid favors the formation of larger crystals for structure characterization. As expected, Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 paddle-wheel secondary building units were formed in situ during the reaction, leading to NbO net (JUC-62) with rectangular 4-connected H4ABTC. As both Cd2+ and Mn2+ ions are six coordinated in which the resulting secondary building units act as tetrahedral nodes, compounds JUC-63 and JUC-64 have PtS topology.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvothermal reactions of Cu(NO3)2⋅(H2O)2.5, Cd(NO3)2⋅(H2O)4, or MnCl2⋅(H2O)4 with H4ABTC organic linker in a slightly acidified mixture DMF/EtOH/H2O or DMF/glycol/H2O readily led to highly crystalline Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2⋅(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3⋅(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64), respectively, in high yield. Addition of a small amount of dilute nitric/muriatic acid favors the formation of larger crystals for structure characterization. As expected, Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 paddle-wheel secondary building units were formed in situ during the reaction, leading to NbO net (JUC-62) with rectangular 4-connected H4ABTC. As both Cd2+ and Mn2+ ions are six coordinated in which the resulting secondary building units act as tetrahedral nodes, compounds JUC-63 and JUC-64 have PtS topology.

elements.content: X-ray crystallography for JUC-62 reveals that each Cu(II) ion is coordinated by five O atoms in pyramidal geometry. A pair of copper-centered pentahedra are bridged by four different carboxylate groups of four independent H4ABTC organic linkers, forming the well-known Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 paddle-wheel units, the Cu···Cu distance is 2.665(1) Å. One H2O molecule binds to each Cu(II) center along the paddle-wheel axis. So the Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 unit is a 4-connected square secondary building unit (SBU) that is defined by the carboxylate carbon atoms (Figure a). While each ABTC4− unit coordinates to four pairs of Cu(II) ions can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU, which is defined by the 3,3′,5, and 5′ carbon atoms (Figure b). Extension of the coordination geometry around each square SBU and rectangular SBU will therefore give a 3D porous framework with NbO-type topology (Figure d). The smaller cage is defined by six paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 inorganic SBUs with a pore diameter of about 9 Å, and the larger rhombic cage is defined by six ABTC4− organic SBUs with a pore diameter of about 11 Å (). There are hexagonal channels with a pore diameter of approximately 9.6 Å viewed along the c axis (Figures c and ). These channels are interconnected through the triangular windows, which can be seen along the a axis (). The void space is filled with two coordinated H2O molecules, one H2O and two DMF guest molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The effective free volume of JUC-62 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 65.9% (0.783 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume without DMF and H2O guest molecules. When removing the terminal H2O molecules, the effective free volume reaches 70.1% (0.888 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray structure of JUC-62: (a) The Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 paddle-wheel unit, which can be viewed as a 4-connected node (yellow, square SBU); (b) the organic linker ABTC4− unit, which coordinates to four Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 units can act as a 4-connected node (blue, rectangular SBU); (c) view along the c axes showing hexagonal channels with a pore diameter of about 9.6 Å; (d) square SBUs (yellow) and rectangular SBUs (blue) form the NbO network. elements.content: X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-63 is also 3D 4-connected network constructed from Cd2(CO2)4(DMF)3 units and ABTC4− units. As shown in Figure a, both Cd(II) ions adopt distorted octahedral coordination geometries with six oxygen atoms and are bridged through three carboxylate groups: two bidentate and one chelating/bridging tridentate. One Cd(II) center has three terminal DMF molecules while the other has one chelating bidentate carboxylates. When the point-of-extension is considered by the carboxylate carbon atoms, this unit is a 4-connected distorted tetrahedral SBU and each ABTC4− unit is surrounded with four pairs of Cd(II) ions that can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU (Figure b). Extension of the coordination geometry around each tetrahedral SBU and rectangular SBU will give a 3D porous framework with PtS-type topology (Figure d). There are open rectangular channels of approximately 6.3 × 10 Å2 along the [011] direction and rhombic channels of 8.3 × 9.6 Å2 along the [100] directions, respectively (Figures c and ). The channels are filled with three coordinated DMF molecules and two DMF guest molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).

The void space is filled with two coordinated DMF molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).

elements.content: The JUC-62 sample was fully activated by the procedure described above in the . The integrity of the framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (). The high-pressure hydrogen storage capability of the activated JUC-62 was evaluated at 77 K. As shown in Figure , the hydrogen adsorption isotherm of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%, which corresponds to a H2 storage capacity of 523.4 mL g−1 (Table ). The value is slightly higher than that of MOF-505 but inferior to those of the two other MOFs using isophthalate derivatives. Although the hydrogen uptake of JUC-62 is lower than some reported MOFs with high hydrogen storage (such as MIL-101, MOF-177, MOF-20, and MOF-5), to the best of our knowledge it is comparable with many MOFs and is higher than “active” carbon (CECA, France) and purified single-walled carbon nanotubes.
elements.clean_text:
High-Pressure Hydrogen Sorption

The JUC-62 sample was fully activated by the procedure described above in the . The integrity of the framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (). The high-pressure hydrogen storage capability of the activated JUC-62 was evaluated at 77 K. As shown in Figure , the hydrogen adsorption isotherm of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%, which corresponds to a H2 storage capacity of 523.4 mL g-1 (Table ). The value is slightly higher than that of MOF-505 but inferior to those of the two other MOFs using isophthalate derivatives. Although the hydrogen uptake of JUC-62 is lower than some reported MOFs with high hydrogen storage (such as MIL-101, MOF-177, MOF-20, and MOF-5), to the best of our knowledge it is comparable with many MOFs and is higher than "active" carbon (CECA, France) and purified single-walled carbon nanotubes.

The density of liquid H2 is 0.0708 g/cm3 at 20 K.

The solid-state excitation−emission spectroscopy of the free H4ABTC ligand, JUC-62 and JUC-63 have been performed at room temperature (Figure ). The emission spectrum for free H4ABTC ligand shows a main peak at 378 nm and a weak shoulder band at 423 nm with λex = 310 nm. Compared with pure H4ABTC ligand, the intense emission peak of JUC-62 is found at 392 nm and a weak shoulder band at 426 nm with an excitation band at 253 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, JUC-63 exhibits a main peak at 402 nm and a shoulder band at 440 nm. The emissions of JUC-62 and JUC-63 are very similar to the free ligand transitions and may be chiefly ligand-centered electronic transitions perturbed by the coordination to metal ions rather than to protons. The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds could find applications as potential fluorescent porous materials.

When excited by 320 nm light, JUC-63 exhibits a main peak at 402 nm and a shoulder band at 440 nm. The emissions of JUC-62 and JUC-63 are very similar to the free ligand transitions and may be chiefly ligand-centered electronic transitions perturbed by the coordination to metal ions rather than to protons. The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds could find applications as potential fluorescent porous materials.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized three 3D porous metal-organic frameworks Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62) with NbO-type topology, Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) with PtS-type topology, constructed from tetra-carboxylic H4ABTC ligand to Cu2+, Cd2+, or Mn2+ ions, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that JUC-62 and JUC-63 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 392 and 402 nm, respectively.

A mixture of Cu(NO3)2·(H2O)2.5 (24 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4ABTC (18 mg, 0.05 mmol) was dissolved in DMF/ethanol/H2O (5:3:1) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. Sufficient 2 M HNO3 was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at 60 °C for 2 days to give blue-green, polyhedral crystals. Yield: 61% (based on H4ABTC). Elemental anal. Calcd C22H26N4O13Cu2 (680): C, 38.82; H, 3.85; N, 8.24. Found: C, 38.91; H, 3.78; N, 8.32.

Synthesis of Cd<sub>2</sub>(ABTC)(DMF)<sub>3</sub>·(DMF)<sub>2</sub> (JUC-63)

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·(H2O)4 (30 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4ABTC (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in DMF/ethanol/H2O (12:3:1) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. Sufficient 2 M HNO3 was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at room temperature for 1 week to give yellowy, block-shaped crystals. Yield: 56% (based on H4ABTC). Elemental anal. Calcd C31H27N7O13Cd2 (932.97): C, 39.87; H, 2.92; N, 10.51. Found: C, 39.72; H, 2.81; N, 10.68.

Synthesis of Mn(H<sub>2</sub>ABTC)(DMF)<sub>2</sub> (JUC-64)

A mixture of MnCl2·(H2O)4 (40 mg, 0.2 mmol) and H4ABTC (11 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in DMF/glycol/H2O (8:2:1) at room temperature in a 25 mL beaker. Sufficient 2 M HCl was added until the mixture became clear. The mixture was left undisturbed at 55 °C for 2 days to give orange, block-shaped crystals. Yield: 73% (based on H4ABTC). Elemental anal. Calcd C22H22N4O10Mn (557.07): C, 47.39; H, 3.98; N, 10.05. Found: C, 47.26; H, 3.82; N, 10.16.

cln_elements.content:
Three 3D multifunctional microporous MOFs, Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62), Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) were synthesized with NbO (JUC-62) and PtS (JUC-63 and JUC-64) nets, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%.

X-ray crystallography for JUC-62 reveals that each Cu(II) ion is coordinated by five O atoms in pyramidal geometry. A pair of copper-centered pentahedra are bridged by four different carboxylate groups of four independent H4ABTC organic linkers, forming the well-known Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 paddle-wheel units, the Cu···Cu distance is 2.665(1) Å. One H2O molecule binds to each Cu(II) center along the paddle-wheel axis. So the Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 unit is a 4-connected square secondary building unit (SBU) that is defined by the carboxylate carbon atoms (Figure a). While each ABTC4− unit coordinates to four pairs of Cu(II) ions can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU, which is defined by the 3,3′,5, and 5′ carbon atoms (Figure b). Extension of the coordination geometry around each square SBU and rectangular SBU will therefore give a 3D porous framework with NbO-type topology (Figure d). The smaller cage is defined by six paddle-wheel Cu2(CO2)4(H2O)2 inorganic SBUs with a pore diameter of about 9 Å, and the larger rhombic cage is defined by six ABTC4− organic SBUs with a pore diameter of about 11 Å (). There are hexagonal channels with a pore diameter of approximately 9.6 Å viewed along the c axis (Figures c and ). These channels are interconnected through the triangular windows, which can be seen along the a axis (). The void space is filled with two coordinated H2O molecules, one H2O and two DMF guest molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The effective free volume of JUC-62 is calculated by PLATON analysis as being 65.9% (0.783 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume without DMF and H2O guest molecules. When removing the terminal H2O molecules, the effective free volume reaches 70.1% (0.888 cm3 g−1) of the crystal volume.

X-ray crystallography reveals that JUC-63 is also 3D 4-connected network constructed from Cd2(CO2)4(DMF)3 units and ABTC4− units. As shown in Figure a, both Cd(II) ions adopt distorted octahedral coordination geometries with six oxygen atoms and are bridged through three carboxylate groups: two bidentate and one chelating/bridging tridentate. One Cd(II) center has three terminal DMF molecules while the other has one chelating bidentate carboxylates. When the point-of-extension is considered by the carboxylate carbon atoms, this unit is a 4-connected distorted tetrahedral SBU and each ABTC4− unit is surrounded with four pairs of Cd(II) ions that can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU (Figure b). Extension of the coordination geometry around each tetrahedral SBU and rectangular SBU will give a 3D porous framework with PtS-type topology (Figure d). There are open rectangular channels of approximately 6.3 × 10 Å2 along the [011] direction and rhombic channels of 8.3 × 9.6 Å2 along the [100] directions, respectively (Figures c and ). The channels are filled with three coordinated DMF molecules and two DMF guest molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).

High-Pressure Hydrogen Sorption

The JUC-62 sample was fully activated by the procedure described above in the . The integrity of the framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (). The high-pressure hydrogen storage capability of the activated JUC-62 was evaluated at 77 K. As shown in Figure , the hydrogen adsorption isotherm of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%, which corresponds to a H2 storage capacity of 523.4 mL g−1 (Table ). The value is slightly higher than that of MOF-505 but inferior to those of the two other MOFs using isophthalate derivatives. Although the hydrogen uptake of JUC-62 is lower than some reported MOFs with high hydrogen storage (such as MIL-101, MOF-177, MOF-20, and MOF-5), to the best of our knowledge it is comparable with many MOFs and is higher than “active” carbon (CECA, France) and purified single-walled carbon nanotubes.

Photoluminescent Properties

The solid-state excitation−emission spectroscopy of the free H4ABTC ligand, JUC-62 and JUC-63 have been performed at room temperature (Figure ). The emission spectrum for free H4ABTC ligand shows a main peak at 378 nm and a weak shoulder band at 423 nm with λex = 310 nm. Compared with pure H4ABTC ligand, the intense emission peak of JUC-62 is found at 392 nm and a weak shoulder band at 426 nm with an excitation band at 253 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, JUC-63 exhibits a main peak at 402 nm and a shoulder band at 440 nm. The emissions of JUC-62 and JUC-63 are very similar to the free ligand transitions and may be chiefly ligand-centered electronic transitions perturbed by the coordination to metal ions rather than to protons. The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds could find applications as potential fluorescent porous materials.

In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized three 3D porous metal-organic frameworks Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2·(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62) with NbO-type topology, Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3·(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) with PtS-type topology, constructed from tetra-carboxylic H4ABTC ligand to Cu2+, Cd2+, or Mn2+ ions, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that JUC-62 and JUC-63 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 392 and 402 nm, respectively.

As shown in Figure a, both Cd(II) ions adopt distorted octahedral coordination geometries with six oxygen atoms and are bridged through three carboxylate groups: two bidentate and one chelating/bridging tridentate. One Cd(II) center has three terminal DMF molecules while the other has one chelating bidentate carboxylates. When the point-of-extension is considered by the carboxylate carbon atoms, this unit is a 4-connected distorted tetrahedral SBU and each ABTC4- unit is surrounded with four pairs of Cd(II) ions that can act as a 4-connected rectangular SBU (Figure b). Extension of the coordination geometry around each tetrahedral SBU and rectangular SBU will give a 3D porous framework with PtS-type topology (Figure d). There are open rectangular channels of approximately 6.3 × 10 Å2 along the [011] direction and rhombic channels of 8.3 × 9.6 Å2 along the [100] directions, respectively (Figures c and ). The channels are filled with three coordinated DMF molecules and two DMF guest molecules, as established by elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). 

High-Pressure Hydrogen Sorption

The JUC-62 sample was fully activated by the procedure described above in the . The integrity of the framework was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (). The high-pressure hydrogen storage capability of the activated JUC-62 was evaluated at 77 K. As shown in Figure , the hydrogen adsorption isotherm of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%, which corresponds to a H2 storage capacity of 523.4 mL g-1 (Table ). The value is slightly higher than that of MOF-505 but inferior to those of the two other MOFs using isophthalate derivatives. Although the hydrogen uptake of JUC-62 is lower than some reported MOFs with high hydrogen storage (such as MIL-101, MOF-177, MOF-20, and MOF-5), to the best of our knowledge it is comparable with many MOFs and is higher than "active" carbon (CECA, France) and purified single-walled carbon nanotubes. 

Photoluminescent Properties

The solid-state excitation-emission spectroscopy of the free H4ABTC ligand, JUC-62 and JUC-63 have been performed at room temperature (Figure ). The emission spectrum for free H4ABTC ligand shows a main peak at 378 nm and a weak shoulder band at 423 nm with λex = 310 nm. Compared with pure H4ABTC ligand, the intense emission peak of JUC-62 is found at 392 nm and a weak shoulder band at 426 nm with an excitation band at 253 nm. When excited by 320 nm light, JUC-63 exhibits a main peak at 402 nm and a shoulder band at 440 nm. The emissions of JUC-62 and JUC-63 are very similar to the free ligand transitions and may be chiefly ligand-centered electronic transitions perturbed by the coordination to metal ions rather than to protons. The difference in their emissions is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because the photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the metal ions and the ligands coordinated around them. These observations suggest that these compounds could find applications as potential fluorescent porous materials. 

In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized and characterized three 3D porous metal-organic frameworks Cu2(ABTC)(H2O)2⋅(DMF)2(H2O) (JUC-62) with NbO-type topology, Cd2(ABTC)(DMF)3⋅(DMF)2 (JUC-63), and Mn(H2ABTC)(DMF)2 (JUC-64) with PtS-type topology, constructed from tetra-carboxylic H4ABTC ligand to Cu2+, Cd2+, or Mn2+ ions, respectively. High-pressure hydrogen sorption of the activated JUC-62 reveals a type I profile at 77 K, which is saturated at 40 bar with a hydrogen uptake of about 4.71 wt%. Photoluminescence investigations reveal that JUC-62 and JUC-63 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 392 and 402 nm, respectively.
